explanation: The report is not correct. Although the expression-statement “(void) cls;” has no runtime effect and could be removed without changing program behaviour, this form is the idiomatic, documented way to mark a parameter intentionally unused and to silence compiler warnings. MISRA’s dead‑code prohibition (Rule 2.2) is aimed at truly redundant operations that indicate logic errors or unnecessary functionality; an explicit discard-expression used solely to document intent / suppress diagnostics is an accepted, benign practice and is not treated as an actionable dead‑code defect in this context. If you prefer to avoid the cast-to-void form you can (a) omit the parameter name in the function definition (void ahc_cb(void * /*cls*/, ...)) or (b) use a project-approved UNUSED macro or attribute, but the presence of “(void) cls;” here should not be considered a Rule 2.2 violation.
